720983f-a.text:
lLexington Avenue, north from East 42nd Street, showing prominently the westerly sida of the arterial thoroughfare. At the loft is the Hotel Commodore. Above samo is the lot where the Graybar Building (420 Lexington Avenue) will be erected. Next in order are,the American Express Co. office building and the old and new units of the Grand Central Palace buildings. The Hotel Barclay is beyond the latter. To the right is the five story structure that was demolished in 1928 for a site for the present Chrysler Building.
December, 1925
Brown Bros.

720984f-a.text:
Lexington Avenue, north From East 42nd Street. To the left is the Hotel Commodore. At the right is the five story holding of Cooper Union. This is to be demolished in 1928 to provide a site for the distinctive Chryslor Building. Note the street car tracks on the Avenue. These will be removed in 1937 by the City thru tho W. P. A. and busses substituted for the trolleys. The tracks on 42nd Street will
remain.
December, 1925
Brown Bros.

712819f-a.text:
152-154 and 156-158 East 42nd Street, south side, between Lexington and Third Avenues. As shown here, the latter is quite new. It contains an entrance to the Queensboro-42nd Street subway line.
About 1925.
W. H. Hinson.

Lexington Avenue, east side, from East 42nd to 43rd Street's, showing the site for the Chrysler Building. To the right is 42nd Street and to the left 43rd. Dpon the latter appears an office structure at the N.E. corner,, several low buildings and St. Agnes R. C. Church. In marly days the Eastern Post Road ran thru hero with its western boundary on tho far side of theexcavation.
December 15, 1928
Peyser & Patzig, Photographers

Park.

(1)
4End Street, north side, at Lexington Avenue; the view is west, showing the old building on the N.E. corner in the last stages of demolition. Notice the campaign poster, for Smith, Robinson,
and Roosevelt, at the corner.
November 1, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A view of the Chrysler Building, a structure that rose on the cleared area shown in N9. 1. This view is northward and shows in the background
the uncompleted, twin towered Waldorf Astoria Hotel.
April 8, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
A similar view to No. 2, showing partially, on the left the Chanin
Building and on the right the News Building.
September 11, 1931.

Lexington Ave., at East 42nd Street (where buildings are located) showing the Chanin Building at the S.W. corner; the Commodore Hotel at the N.W. corner and the uncompleted Chrysler Building at the N.E. corner. This view is photographed in a northwestward direction from a point east
of Third Ave. near 35th Street.
About 1930.
Ewing Galloway.

720981f.text:

The direction of view is southwestward.
About 1931
Ewing Galloway

730400f-b.title: General view - [Manhattan - Lexington Avenue - 42nd Street (East) - Chanin Building.]
730400f-b.text:
A general view northward from atop the Chanin Bldg., located at the S. W . corner of Lexington Avenue and E. 42nd Street, showing a panoramic arrangement of the Grand Central 2one and the area to the north. View 1 shows the midtown section between Sixth Avenue (left) and Lexington Avenue (right). This contains the 70 story R.C.A. Bldg., the Grand Central Bldg., the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, and the Teneral Electric Bldg. In the center background is Central Park. View 2 shows the East Side- Yorkville fringe of Manhattan. Here are numerous apartment houses, hotela, tenements and lofts. These are framed by the G.. Bldg on the left and the Chrysler on right. The white pile in the center background near the East River is The New York Hospital and Cornell University Medical College. This is to the north of the queensboro Bridge and opposite Welfare Island. The latter lies in the center of the East Eiver and was formerly known as Blackwells Island. Beyond this appears the Astoria section of Aueens, the Triboro and the Hellgate dridges,
and the distant outline of the Bronx.
730400f-b.folder: Lexington Avenue - 42nd Street (East) - Chanin Building., Manhattan, NY

730400f-a.title: General view - [Manhattan - Lexington Avenue - 42nd Street (East) - Chanin Building.]
730400f-a.text:
A general view northward from atop the Chanin Bldg., located at the S. W . corner of Lexington Avenue and E. 42nd Street, showing a panoramic arrangement of the Grand Central 2one and the area to the north. View 1 shows the midtown section between Sixth Avenue (left) and Lexington Avenue (right). This contains the 70 story R.C.A. Bldg., the Grand Central Bldg., the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, and the Teneral Electric Bldg. In the center background is Central Park. View 2 shows the East Side- Yorkville fringe of Manhattan. Here are numerous apartment houses, hotela, tenements and lofts. These are framed by the G.. Bldg on the left and the Chrysler on right. The white pile in the center background near the East River is The New York Hospital and Cornell University Medical College. This is to the north of the queensboro Bridge and opposite Welfare Island. The latter lies in the center of the East Eiver and was formerly known as Blackwells Island. Beyond this appears the Astoria section of Aueens, the Triboro and the Hellgate dridges,
and the distant outline of the Bronx.
730400f-a.folder: Lexington Avenue - 42nd Street (East) - Chanin Building., Manhattan, NY

730401f-b.title: General view - [Manhattan - Lexington Avenue - 42nd Street (East) - Chanin Building.]
730401f-b.text:
A general view eastward towards the East niver from the Chanin Building at the S.o. corner of Lexington Avenue and E. 42nd Street, showing in a set of three views, a panoramic arrangement. View 1 emphasizes the midtown East Side area with its New York Hospital-Cornell University Medical College Center; No. 2, the publishing zone at 43rd, 44th and 45th Streets; and No. 3, Tudor City and the Edison electric plant. In the background, across the River, is the Long Island City sector of the Borough of Queens. Note the Queensboro Bridge extending towards same across the river and Welfare Island. The buildings partly shown at the various margins are the Chrysler and
the News.
October 3, 1936
Views 1,2 and 3
P. L. Sperr
730401f-b.folder: Lexington Avenue - 42nd Street (East) - Chanin Building., Manhattan, NY

730403f-a.title: General view - [Manhattan - Lexington Avenue - 42nd Street (East) - Chanin Building.]
730403f-a.text:
A general view Southeastward from atop the Chanin Building at the S.W. corner of Lexington Avenue and E. 42nd Street, showing that Manhattan area sometimes called Murray Hill. Lexington Avenue is on the extreme right in View 2 and the diagonal thoroughfares are Third and Second Avenues. To the left is St. Gabriels Park, near the East
Niver.
October 3, 1936
Views 1 and 2
L. Sperr
730403f-a.folder: Lexington Avenue - 42nd Street (East) - Chanin Building., Manhattan, NY

720979f-a.text:
A general view northward from the Chanin Building at the S. W. corner of Lexington Avenue and E. 42nd Street, showing the Grand Central 2one of Manhattan. These three views form a panorawic arrangement depicting respectively Rockefeller City with its 70 storied R.C.A. Building, the Grand Central Building; and the Waldorf-storia Hotel. The North (Hudson) River and its Jersey Highlands is on the left. In the center appears Central Park. Lexington Avenue is the thoroughfare running thru the center of No. 3.
October 3, 1936
Views 1, 2 and 3
P. L. Sperr
Ne. ~ 1E9

712804f-a.text:
East 42nd Street, (not shown) from Second to Lexington Avenue's. Between these two thoroughfares lie the depicted News and Chrysler Buildings. The former is midway between Second and Third Avenue's, while the latter is at the N.E. corner of Lexington Avenue. The view is northeastward from a rooftop at 40th Street.
September 16, 1940
